data.title: New reflected Class not included when executing the application with GWT superDev mode
data.body:
#### Issue details
It seems like the reflection cache isn't updated, when you test the application with the GWT superDev mode (`gradle html:superDev`). This leads to the error `Couldn't find Type for class`, when the application is recompiled, after a new class thats used with reflection has been added.

#### Reproduction steps/code
1. Include an empty package to the reflection
```
<module>
	<source path="com.application" />
	
	<extend-configuration-property name="gdx.reflect.include" value="com.application.reflect.me" />
</module>
```
2. Start the code server (e.g. with `gradle html:superDev`)
3. Test that the application runs error free
4. Create a new class in the previously added package and create a new instance with the reflection API
5. Recompile the application

#### Workaround
1. Stop the coder server
2. ~~Package the application for the web (e.g. with `gradle html:dist`)~~
3. Start the code server again

If there's no way to fix this properly, please add a note to the [reflection wiki page](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/Reflection#gwt).

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
1.9.6-SNAPSHOT

data.title: Lwjgl3 backend report event timestamp instead of current time.
data.body:
This is a feature request and PR that would affect the Lwjgl3 backend.  It's about reporting of input event timestamps to users.  

## Background
I think the expected way to access event timestamps is to call `Gdx.input.getCurrentEventTime()` during `InputProcessor` callbacks like `keyUp()`.  For example:
```
    @Override
    public boolean keyUp(int keycode) {
        System.out.println("Event time is: " + Gdx.input.getCurrentEventTime());
        return false;
    }
```
 From the [comments/docs](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/Input.java#L709), this should return the timestamp of the current event being handled.

## Current State
I think the current implementation of `Lwjgl3Input` is actually returning the time when the most recent event was enqueued for processing, rather than the time when the currently-being-handled event occurred.

This is because the `Lwjgl3Input.currentEventTime` is only updated as events are enqueued, and then reported to the user during `getCurrentEventTime()`.

So, the timestamps for events that were enqueued earlier might be ignored and replaced with a later time stamp.

## Suggested Change
I suggest that `Lwjgl3Input` should report event timestamps by delegating to its `InputEventQueue`, instead of keeping its own `currentEventTime` field.

This would take advantage of the fact that `InputEventQueue` updates its own `currentEventTime` field each time it dequeues an event and makes an `InputProcessor` callback.

Here is a PR with the specific change that I suggest: #4513.

## Happiness
Thank you very much for libgdx!  It is a great project and I am excited to be working with it!

data.title: Performance improvement when clearing *Map classes
data.body:
When clearing a Map instance the `keyTable` array is traversed in reverse order when setting the array elements to `EMPTY`, thus clearing the array.

When iterating in 'normal' order the JVM seems to be able to optimize the loop and can see great improvements.

Current code (excerpt from IntIntMap.clear()):
```java
for (int i = capacity + stashSize; i-- > 0;)
	keyTable[i] = EMPTY;
```

Changing it to
```java
for (int i = 0, n = capacity + stashSize; i < n; i++)
	keyTable[i] = EMPTY;
```

or even using `Arrays.fill(keyTable, 0, capacity + stashSize, EMPTY);` brings noticable performance improvements.

Stumbled upon it when doing tests with ModelCache and changing the IntIntMap as mentioned brought an improvement from ~200 to ~250 fps (just for reference, ignoring what and how it was being tested) clearly showing this change can be useful.

Other Map classes should be changed in the same way.

Can contribute with a push request, just can't do it sometime soon, but leaving this suggestion in case someone has any interest in doing it first.

data.title: Create common interface for container classes in com.badlogic.gdx.utils
data.body:
Looks like all Collection/Map alike utility classes have at least two things in common - size and ability to clear. Utility methods that question object 'emptyness' would be much easier to implement if all those classes would share a common interface e.g.:

    public interface Container {
        int size();
    
        void clear();
    }

Some of classes already implement interface Iterable and the 'emptyness' could be checked by Iterator, but this triggers creating Iterator instance if there was no need for one before. 

This interface could be implemented by:
 - Array
 - ArrayMap
 - BooleanArray
 - ObjectSet
 - ObjectMap
 - ObjectIntMap
 - ObjectFloatMap
 - LongMap
 - LongArray
 - IntSet
 - IntMap
 - IntIntMap
 - IntFloatMap
 - IntArray
 - IdentityMap
 - FloatArray
 - CharArray
 - ByteArray
 - BooleanArray
 - Queue
 - ShortArray
 - SortedIntList
 - PooledLinkedList

This could be a humble beginning for further API generalisation on this classes if needed.

data.title: root in TiledMapLoader.loadAsync is not set
data.body:
#### Issue details
I get this exception when I try to load a TiledMap asynchronously.
```java
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.badlogic.gdx.maps.tiled.TmxMapLoader.loadTilemap(TmxMapLoader.java:158)
	at com.badlogic.gdx.maps.tiled.TmxMapLoader.loadAsync(TmxMapLoader.java:110)
```

#### Reproduction steps/code
Trivial reproduction.
Initialize a new TmxMapLoader, and use the loadAsync method.
Here's the line of code that causes grief:
`String mapOrientation = root.getAttribute("orientation", null);`
Clearly, "root" is the null exception.

However, even if root was set, loadAsync assumes that the required dependancies (i.e. texture files) have already been loaded, so it still fails (I tried running loadAsync after a call to "getDependancies" and I still get exceptions regarding loads).
So loadAsync isn't really "loadAsync".  I can't finish loading the required dependancies either because I'm on a different thread, which means, I'd have to load them in from outside in a thread with the OpenGL context.

All this to say: loadAsync, doesn't seems to work as intended?

Am I using loadAsync incorrectly?

Thanks.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
Latest

#### Stacktrace
Provided above

Probably affects all platforms.

data.title: [BUG] UIApplication.sharedApplication().delegate().window(), MOE will Crash
data.body:
libgdx 1.9.5, MOE gradle plugin 1.2.5
## 1.Reproduction
Just write the code in ``` applicationDidFinishLaunchingWithOptions ```

```
UIApplication.sharedApplication().delegate().window(),
```
the app will crased by error:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2835129/21260152/9a288bf0-c3bf-11e6-9965-4ee5085aec21.png)

## 2.Reason
I found the reason, because the moe-backends not override the window method in IOSApplication
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2835129/21260200/d7f2e4ee-c3bf-11e6-931b-e2b7c3e849e6.png)
## 3.Solution
So I download the source code of moe-backends, and override the window().
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2835129/21260257/058b4072-c3c0-11e6-9af2-91143d435f7d.png)

## 4.Effects
And then the app will run normal. I do not know how to "Pull requests", so please add the code in the IOSApplication.java. Thank you.
